Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Network Infrastructure: The Future of Research and Collaboration: The Dedicated Science Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing two new major components for Yale's network infrastructure: a dedicated, 100-Gigabits-per-second Science Network, and a Science DMZ. In combination with a high-speed connection to the national Internet2 network, these components are designed to enable collaborations involving Yale scientists and researchers throughout the world on computation- and data-intensive research projects in astronomy, climatology, genomics, and other scientific fields.

The on-campus Science Network provides a 100-fold increase in speed over the networks currently in use. Using it, Yale scientists, from their desktops, can rapidly access both multi-Petabyte network-attached data storage facilities, and any of the university's high performance computing clusters. Such a dramatic increase in network speed is a game changer for scientists who regularly deal with Terabyte-size and larger datasets, reducing transfer times from many hours to just a few minutes. The addition of the Science DMZ enables researchers to share results outside Yale and to access national data repositories and computational infrastructure such as XSEDE.

The project builds on Yale's prior investments in both the InCommon authentication framework (which allows external collaborators to use network credentials from their home institutions to access resources at Yale), and IPv6 technology (which allows broader and more efficient access to networked devices). The investigators are using perfSONAR appliances to collect performance data that will allow them to optimize and manage the topology of the network infrastructure and validate the performance gains it delivers.

Broader Impact: In essence, this project is creating a virtual facility for scientific collaboration and data sharing that will allow new research communities and collaborations to form within its walls. By leveraging the Science Network and Science DMZ, Yale will be able to pioneer new modes of research collaboration; host and serve up "big data" scientific data stores; and work with institutions in its region, across the nation, and around the world to broaden the opportunities for scientific research, and support excellent education and training for students at all levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project designed and deployed two major new components of the campus network infrastructure at Yale University: a 100-Gigabits-per-second Science Network, and a Science DMZ, both dedicated to high-performance data transfer in support of scientific research. (See attached network diagram.) The result has been a dramatic improvement in the ability of Yale researchers to manage, move, and share large data sets. This will improve scientific research at Yale and lead to enhanced collaborations with colleagues across the country and throughout the world on computation- and data-intensive research projects in astronomy, climatology, genomics, and other scientific fields.

The new Science Network implementation funded by this project connects two specific departmental computing facilities (in Astronomy and Geology & Geophysics) with the Science DMZ, a multi-Petabyte network-attached storage facility, and two high-performance-computing centers on campus. It provides up to a 100-fold increase in speed as compared to the networks previously used at Yale. The time required to move typical multi-Terabyte-size datasets has been reduced from many hours to just a few minutes, leading to improvements in researchers’ efficiency, and reducing the need to replicate large data sets in active use at multiple locations on campus.

The Science DMZ takes advantage of new high-speed connections to the national Internet2 network installed during the project. It also leverages the Globus Connect file-sharing software from the Globus Project, as well as Yale’s prior investment in the InCommon authentication framework, which allows external collaborators to use network credentials from their home institutions to access resources at Yale. The result is that Yale researchers now have far better access to national data repositories and computational infrastructure such as XSEDE, and they can share results with outside collaborators easily and rapidly.

Leveraging this project, the university has funded additional investments in cyberinfrastructure to extend the 100-Gigabits-per-second network backbone to additional campus locations (departments and key laboratories) during 2015 and beyond. These cyberinfrastructure improvements will allow Yale to participate in scientific research and innovation in new and better ways, for example by hosting regional repositories of global scientific data and pioneering new forms of collaboration and new partnerships that depend crucially on high-performance networks. This will benefit not only Yale’s research mission, but also its educational mission at all levels.
